awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Mathematical models for uncovering neurological disorders among the U.S. population infected with COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 virus has been statistically linked to specific medical disorders connected to the brain and nervous system. Although in the past a fraction of SARS and MER patients have been shown to have anxiety and other neurological disorders, the scale of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 and 2021 is another order of magnitude. The reasons for neurological disorders among COVID-19 patients in the U.S. and other countries are not clear, but the data indicate that some of COVID-19 patients have issues with their awareness, consciousness, and cognizance. Experiments have been conducted on patients worldwide and data was recorded on the behavior of COVID-19 patients. In this project, the principal investigators will develop a mathematical model for an understanding of these neurological mechanisms. The model to be developed will be validated and verified. Once the model is calibrated with data from the U.S. and other countries, the investigators will study the role of COVID in developing brain disorders. They will combine the predictability of the model according to the stochastic volatility of the parameters. The results will have an important impact on the overall well-being of the population and society as a whole.

If uncertainty concerning the reasons behind brain damage continues then that could further increase the number of people in the U.S. who would have neurological disorders. In spite of the positive influence of vaccination programs, COVID-19 causes some of neurological disorders among the current patients. Along with the COVID-19 burden, hospitals and health administrators need to understand other long-term, brain-related disorders in the population. A good, quantitative study will be of immediate help in controlling the incidence of brain-related damaged individuals who have COVID-19 in the U.S. The investigators intend to provide a free consultation to neuro-physicians across the nation if and when they need any immediate quantitative assistance in predictions (within a limited time frame). The investigators will develop a mathematical model to understand the size and complexity of the association between brain deterioration and COVID-19 in the U.S. Specifically, they will predict and evaluate people in the U.S. who will likely have neurological disorders like psychosis, hemorrhage, delirium, and stroke. Clinical data have shown some association, but why there are such causes of disorders for the COVID patients is not yet clear from these studies. Several studies among COVID patients have found a statistical correlation between clinical case definitions for psychiatric diagnoses and intracerebral hemorrhage. Another uncertainty remains in understanding the impact of COVID in blood-brain barrier locations; clinical studies are in progress in this direction. A statistical regression analysis on a large clinical population might provide an association among various independent variables of neurological disorders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The COVID-19 virus has produced considerable anxiety in the American population. That is already one serious brain-oriented consequence of the disease. It has been predicted that the suicide rate would increase because of COVID, although that has not yet been documented. What we are noting here is that the virus can be statistically linked to specific medical disorders connected to the brain and nervous system. This development will have a serious impact on the functioning of society and on the overall well-being of the population. Our framework of the project is fundamentally novel to understanding the association among neurological data available from various COVID-19 sources.

 

Broader Impacts: The reported number of COVID-19 cases by the World Health Organization from Jan. 1, 2020, to May 6, 2022, is 513,955,910 cases reported deaths during this period 6,190,349.  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, COVID-19 death numbers already became a top killer next to heart-related deaths and cancer in the United States.  The models we build predicted that global underreporting of cases ranging from 1 in 1.2 to 1 in 4.7 actual cases (Figure 1).  We estimate the global COVID-19 cases between 600 million and 2.4 billion cases. Our models help in assessing indirect implications of the pandemic, like the community-level true scenario of long-term neurological and mental disorders in the U..S. and other countries.

 

We have computed the average life lost due to COVID-19 in the U.S. The average remaining years who died in the age group 18-29 is 56.2 years for aged 30-39 is 45.9 years; for the aged 40-49 is 36.9 years, for aged 50-64 is 25.8 years, for the aged 65-74 is 10.8 years, for the aged 75-84 is 9.6, and for the aged 85+ is 4.0 years. We have published a special issue on COVID-19 and analysis in the Journal of Mathematical Analysis and Applications. We are also preparing to submit a full proposal on modeling through PDEs for a better understanding of the disease dynamics and spread under multi-morbid conditions within the population.  Still there are open questions related to bonding of COVID-19 virus spikes with uninfected cells in the human body (Figure 2.2). The developed models test the size and complexity of the association between brain deterioration and COVID-19 in the U.S. We have developed a few more candidate models and these are in the testing stage. Specifically, we wish to predict and evaluate people in the US who will likely have neurological disorders like psychosis, hemorrhage, delirium, and stroke. The COVID-19 spread from throat areas to lungs can be prevented by timely intervention (Figure 3.2). Clinical data did show some association but why there are such causes of disorders for the COVID patients is not yet clear from these studies.

 

      More experiments have been conducted on patients worldwide and data was recorded on the behavior of the COVID patients. Once the model gets calibrated in the U.S. and other countries, we wish to study the role of COVID in developing brain disorders. We wish to mix the predictability of the model according to the stochastic volatility of the parameters.

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2022
Modified by: Arni Rao

Images (1 of )
  • Meyer wavelets on reported cases
    Krantz, S.G., Swanson, D.A., Rao, A.S.R.S. (2022). Global Under-reporting of COVID-19 cases during January 1, 2020 to May 6, 2022. Current Science,123, 6: 741-742.
    Copyrighted
    Arni Rao
    Figure 1
  • Bonding of COVID-19 virus spikes and uninfected cells
    Srinivasa Rao, Arni S. R.; Krantz, Steven G. Mathematical analysis and topology of SARS-CoV-2, bonding with cells and unbonding. J. Math. Anal. Appl. 514 (2022), no. 2, Paper No. 125664, 13 pp.
    Copyrighted
    Arni Rao
    Figure 2.2
  • COVID-19 spread from throat to lungs
    Srinivasa Rao, Arni S. R.; Krantz, Steven G. Mathematical analysis and topology of SARS-CoV-2, bonding with cells and unbonding. J. Math. Anal. Appl. 514 (2022), no. 2, Paper No. 125664, 13 pp.
    Copyrighted
    Arni Rao
    Figure 3.2
